description: Measurement sphere object for monitoring local physical quantities in PFC. Obtained via itasca.measure.find() or itasca.measure.list().
note: Objects of this type should not be created (instantiated) directly in Python. Use module functions that return instances.

methods.name: id
methods.description: Get the measure id

returns.description: The unique ID number of this measurement object

methods.name: valid
methods.description: Returns True if this measure is live

returns.description: True if the measurement object exists in the model, False otherwise

methods.name: delete
methods.description: Delete this measurement object
notes: After calling delete(), the object reference becomes invalid

methods.name: pos
methods.description: Get the measure location (vector)

returns.description: 3D vector (x, y, z) representing the measurement sphere center

methods.name: pos_x
methods.description: Get the x-component of the measure location

returns.description: X-coordinate of the measurement sphere center

methods.name: pos_y
methods.description: Get the y-component of the measure location

returns.description: Y-coordinate of the measurement sphere center

methods.name: pos_z
methods.description: Get the z-component of the measure location

returns.description: Z-coordinate of the measurement sphere center

methods.name: set_pos
methods.description: Set the measure location (vector)

methods.name: set_pos_x
methods.description: Set the x-component of the measure location

methods.name: set_pos_y
methods.description: Set the y-component of the measure location

methods.name: set_pos_z
methods.description: Set the z-component of the measure location

methods.name: radius
methods.description: Get the measure radius

methods.name: set_radius
methods.description: Set the measure radius

methods.name: coordination
methods.description: Get the measure coordination

returns.description: Average coordination number (contacts per particle) within the measurement sphere

methods.name: porosity
methods.description: Get the measure porosity

returns.description: Porosity value (void ratio) within the measurement sphere

methods.name: size
methods.description: Get a numpy array of the cumulative size distribution falling within this measure object where nbin is the number of bins for the size distribution calculation

returns.description: 2D array where each row contains [size, cumulative_fraction]

methods.name: strainrate
methods.description: Get the strain rate tensor calculated for this measurement object

methods.name: strainrate_full
methods.description: Get the full strain rate tensor calculated for this measurement object

methods.name: stress
methods.description: Get the stress tensor calculated for this measurement object

methods.name: stress_full
methods.description: Get the full stress tensor calculated for this measurement object

usage_examples.title: Monitor stress in a region
usage_examples.code:
# Create measurement sphere (via PFC command)
itasca.command('measure create id 1 position (5,5,5) radius 2.0')

# Access and monitor
measure = itasca.measure.find(1)
if measure:
    stress = measure.stress()
    porosity = measure.porosity()
    print(f'Stress: {stress}, Porosity: {porosity}')

usage_examples.title: Track measurements over time
usage_examples.code:
# During cycling
for step in range(1000):
    itasca.command('cycle 100')
    measure = itasca.measure.find(1)
    if measure:
        coord = measure.coordination()
        strain = measure.strainrate()
        print(f'Step {step}: coord={coord:.2f}, strain={strain}')

usage_examples.title: Multiple measurement spheres
usage_examples.code:
# Create multiple measurement locations
locations = [(0,0,0), (5,0,0), (0,5,0)]
for i, (x, y, z) in enumerate(locations, 1):
    itasca.command(f'measure create id {i} pos ({x},{y},{z}) radius 1.5')

# Collect data from all
for measure in itasca.measure.list():
    pos = measure.pos()
    stress = measure.stress()
    print(f'Measure {measure.id()} at {pos}: stress={stress}')

see_also: PFC MEASURE commands for creation and configuration
